Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Overall snowpack stable. Layer of concern is between new snowfall and wind loaded layer. Stability tests showed that the layer is starting to bound as sheer characteristic is non-planer (with Q3).

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope

User.name: Andy Anderson
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Able to access this area, which is pretty much representative of back country conditions, because of explosives work done two days prior.
Did not find near surface facets at the Jan 1 interface in the St Elmo area.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Total Height of snow: 280cm / Weak layer at snow density change (96cm). Unable to produce propagation in large column tests. No red flags for avalanche danger observed along tour today. Right side up snowpack. Widespread 2-5 cm crust, large rain runnels and effects of rain on snow up to 6,000 feet, all aspects on the west side today. Above 6k, soft, dry and light powder. South facing aspects, even with 25 degree F air temp, began to experience roller ball action. Full sun all day. Riming on all trees and surface of snowpack. A lot of surface hoar observed that has formed over the past night or two.

User.name: Nick Meyers
User.affil: Mt Shasta Avalanche Center - Shasta/Trinity Nat'l Forest

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No obvious signs of instability. Temperature inversion. Steeper sun exposed slopes above 8500 feet had moist surface snow or mf crust.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Old tracks covered by new PP
There was a dirty crust observed in part of the snowpit. The crust was preset throughout, but in once section of the pit it was much more pronounced.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
We skied slope
Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: First above treeline observation/pit since atmospheric river event/January storm cycle. Overall snow surface very smooth with isolated sastrugi wind erosional features. Fairly uniform surface hardness, soft mostly with hard slabs and packed powder throughout terrain. Skiers and snowmobilers riding similar slopes. Windy, NE, blowing snow onto westerly slopes. Chilly today but sunny! Unknown total height of snow, couldn't hit ground! A lot of wind loading but no recent avalanches. Observations and tests looking at wind slab stability. Danger perceived as moderate. Moderate to hard resistant planar fractures 35cm down at density break in hard wind slab. Full slope propagation unlikely unless perhaps multiple riders on slope at a time.

User.name: Nick Meyers
User.affil: Mt Shasta Avalanche Center - Shasta/Trinity Nat'l Forest

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 2 ice layers showing in the snowpack. One sun crust about 40cm from the surface was causing results in our CT end ECT test, along with the rain crust from oct/nov about 40cm from the base of the snowpack. 5cm ski pen. Surface Hoar growth was observed. No signs of avalanches, cracking or woomfing in our zone today. Another group did get results with a ski cut and observed a crown on Breccia. The Snowpack was overall more stable than expected. Layer of concern will be the areas above and below the most recent crust on this aspect. As well as the possibility of stepping down to the rain crust layer and below into 3mm Depth Hoar / Basal Facets
Looked like we were in Japan. Incredible amount of new snow.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We dug several hasty pits on other aspects and saw similar results. Some evidence of windloading and scouring.

User.name: Aaron Beverly

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in the upper reaches of the start zone for Scotty's. South winds at ridge tops but the wind was coming from the West in this terrain feature. The primary concern is facets above a 2mm ice lens possibly formed by rime on the 7th pm or 8th am. No propagation was observed but as the overlying slab thickens and gains tensile strength I would become more concerned about propagation on this weak layer. Today the overlying slab was fist hardness and propagation was quick to arrest however shears were easy.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Above 8000ft, the snowpack remained dry and was not affected by the 01/08 rain event. The wet snow that fell at this elevation on 01/08 now exists as a supportable 6cm thick MFcr. Height of new snow since 01/06 is 51cm.

User.name: David Reichel
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Heavily wind loaded site. HOWEVER, we looked at many other locations at elevations above this and the facets found in our other pit above the very hard and thick ice/rain crust were not as faceted. The rain/ice crust was thinner and softer. Perhaps these two features correlate with each other. Additionally we could barely get that layer to break in tests.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Dug on due S and N at similar elevations. Found similar structure and similar results. May be thin layer of facets just above crust at 71-70 cm. This pit dug adjacent to a loaded slope that was triggered on 12/27. Bed surf appeared to be thick crust at 63 cm. Soft fx'd layer (63-70 cm) formed when it rained, some snow fell, then temperatures got very cold. This wx event was applied to all aspects at similar elevations. We did many ECT's and got the same results. It was a very stubborn layer despite being so faceted. I was surprised.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Lee Watson
Saw drifting and windloaded in open areas. Checked other aspects and saw similar results.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Base depth variable, small shrub/tree and boulders in pit area. Facet's between the DEC 16 and DEC 21 rain crust appear to be rounding, most likely due to clear/calm/warmer conditions since the DEC 24/25 storm cycle

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in open 30m x 70m area below treeline. PST performed at 50cm had fracture move up to 54 cm height for end propagation.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: winds picked up after noon

Pit_Observation.activities: We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Past 48 hour northwest wind event created a scoured snowpack consisting of all forms of snow surfaces: breakable crust, hard slabs, wind buff, soft powder, icy crusts, protruding sastrugi features and old ski/snowmobile tracks. 12/23 persistent weak layer still present just below crust (21cm) with Q1 shears in small column tests, however ECT test could not produce propagation. Total HS: 231cm

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown face of snowboarder triggered avalanche that occurred on 12-19-2016. Crown depths ranged from 2 feet to 10 feet. Average was probably 4 feet. Width was 730 feet. Maximum vertical was 1,100 feet. US classification of this avalanche is HS-AR-R3-D3-G

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We dug this pit on our approach to the crown of a deep slab avalanche triggered by a snowboarder.
Pretty sheltered down in Stump Hollow, but I could see some drifting up higher.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Avalanche ran approximately 12/17 SS-N-R2-D2-I
Brush in bottom of pit.
Strong winds but not enough load to cause problems. I would't ski any steep, wind loaded slopes below the ridgelines.
Winds increased to 30 mph plus afternoon. Wind and blowing snow in the pit made gathering information difficult..

We used the BTNF photo (4 Pines North Dec 4) and probed for a difference in slab thickness to site the pit. Our main concern was stability on the Oct crusts -the former bed surface from Dec 4. We cut above and below the crusts. If we were able to cut to half way, we stopped the cut to help preserve the beam so that we could cut other interfaces above. In hindsight it might be better to cut all the way and take the chance of the beam sliding off. The new snow seems to be bonding well to the old bed surface. The bottom Layer in the pit represents the Oct snow.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Basal facets were impressively weak in this location but between the rocky ground and ice layer just above them, I was unable to drag a saw through the layer to test them using a PST.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown Profile. HS-NS-R3-D3. The avalanche likely occurred between the afternoon of 12/16 and the early morning of 12/17. The width of the avalanche was 1500ft, the vertical run was 2000ft, and the crown height ranged from 1-6ft. Debris was 10-20ft deep minimum. The majority of the avalanche involved recent wind deposited snow. In a rocky, 150 foot section of the crown where this crown profile was conducted, the avalanche stepped down and failed on a much deeper layer of old snow.

We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpack is surprisingly solid despite an ECTP22 near the ground. There are very few layers to find in the snowpack. The layer at 90 was settling fast, and we noticed a big difference in our track penetration by the end of the day. In many places this layer is not a concern. In other places, probably places where you are more likely to hit a rock with your snowmobile, the facets near the ground are probably worse.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Snowpit: Not a full pit. I recorded hand hardness for layer id and did stability tests. ECTP 25 @ 155 (the layer below yesterday's rain crust). Modified ECTP 14 @ 62cm - I removed snow from the column until only 1m of snow remained on top of the facet layer at 62 cm. PST 0/165 END @ 62cm - Test failed during isolation.

User.name: Andy Anderson
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Nearest sensors indicating around 3-4'' of rain in this area in the last 24 hours. Rain turned to snow sometime late yesterday/early morning with around 7cm of high density snow on top. Below new surface snow rain crust has not been able to freeze yet and is punchy in most areas.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Uneven rocky ground in our pit location sabotaged our PST attempt. We did a Deep Tap Test and got a DTH (23) at the ground, but again the rough rocky terrain somewhat compromised this result. Basal facets in this location were less weak than recent observations at Elephants Back and Stevens Peak.

User.name: Aaron Beverly

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit from top of moraine in flute. Test pit to test Dec 10 outflow layers. Burp Test resulted in moderate results above and below Dec 10 outflow layer on facets, spotty S.H.

Pit_Observation.activities: Snowmobile tracks on slope; We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: All our snowpits looked similar and had similar depth. There was widespread natural activity on the layer at 95cm. Both at ridgetops under cornices and at lower non-wind loaded locations. The facets near the ground are likely worse in some places. In all our other snowpits they looked better and were stonger. Overall the snowpack looks pretty good. With tonights snow, it will most like produce more avalanches at the 95cm layer. With such a large load forecasted, there will likely be places where avalanches step down, but this will not be a widespread issue.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Recent activity on similar slopes
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug adjacent to recent wind slab avalanche that occurred sometime during recent storm. Period of high avalanche danger very short lived. Warm storm followed by cool temps and wind has created a nicely consolidated layer of homogenous new snow capped by 1-2 cm temp crust. Total height of snowpack: 190 cm. / Height of new snow: 48 cm / Height of pit dug: 95cm (down to old snow, rock solid)

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking
Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Ski tracks on slope; Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit was dug in the flank of an avalanche. Whats interesting is that the stauchwall (the bottom edge of the slab that released) was very far downslope almost near the deposition area of avalanche debris. There was a similar slide but smaller at a similar aspect and elevation on Peak 10420. That slope tilts a little bit more north. It was triggered by snowboarders mid slope. For this avalanche we don't know how it was triggered.
This is an AIARE Level II data pit class exercise

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ben Bernal and Seth Carbonari observers. Clouds breaking through the day. No identifiable weaknesses above or below early Dec ice layer. Some small surface hoar development identified between 5000 and 6500 feet in sheltered areas.
Good stability. No fractures in small column tests. Rain runnels visible on snow surface.

Snowmobile tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We consistently got ECTP's with scores of 13 to 15 on a thin layer of small facets that formed on top of the old snow surface. This layer was consistently 4-8 inches above the ground depending on the snow depth prior to 48 hours ago. Despite these scores we did not observe any cracking or collapsing which surprised me given the rapid heavy load of snow.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Ski penetration was 0 cms in pit location. On the ski out, the crust was horrendously breakable. Test results were not perfectly repeatable on basal weak layer but were generally repeatable.

User.name: Steve Reynaud
User.affil: Tahoe National Forest Sierra Avalanche Center

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: The faceted layer between 50 and 60 seemed worse on more easterly aspects that got some solar input. These aspects seemed to have more structure in the snowpack and produced ECTP's. Also, we consistently got the layers at 65 and 60 cm's to break when we stepped above a snowpit or above a skin track. North aspect actually seemed to have a better snowpack. S aspects had crusts and lots of facets. I think S aspects are so faceted because they had a much shallower snowpack during recent cold weather.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope
We skied slope
Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: W aspect in Beehive Basin. Shallow. Just enough slab to get propagation on the basal weak layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Crown profile of AS / AR triggerd avalanche. This avalanche was 30' wide, upto 4' deep and run about 250'. thia avalanche was confuned to a single wind pilow.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit is in location where we triggered a localized collapse

Layer of concern was a density break within the storm snow. Easy failures with SC results in small column tests, but no propagation in large column tests possibly due to the slab thickness (15-20cm). The recent storm has created an upside down hardness configuration in the top 15-20cm due to a warming trend throughout the storm. Freezing rain in the afternoon has capped the new snow of with a 4F hard zipper crust on all aspects up to 8000ft+

Debbie Kelly, Steve Schreiber

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very deep trail breaking, localized collapsing. Not much wind effect. Location was in an area of burned trees from the 1988 fire season.

The 27cm to 5cm facet layer showed signs of some rounding occurring throughout layer. Towards the top of this layer, just below the rain crust, facets were up to 1.5mm in size and more angular. At 62cm old buried surface hoar found during snowpack tests with limited reactivity.

Did a Extended Column ECTX and PST 90/100 Arr (on ground so not a good test). Apparently Snowpilot does not allow you o enter the depth for ECTs or PSTs. A somewhat cumbersome entry system as well. I'll try using chrome next time. Cannot enter on Ipad at all.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit was down-slope from ridge 100ft. Surface had very thin wind-skin. Winds building thicker slabs closer to ridge crest.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Quick Pit....Stability very good in this area. Uniform density and isothermal snowpack. Could not clearly identify any layers of concern at this point. No recent or past avy debris visible. Cold temps. Some areas hosting small surface hoar. Cold and clear nights to come could cause further surface hoar growth. Not an issue now until we get more snow on top, maybe our next weak layer. No concerns at this point. Rime ice on trees and rocks along ridge lines.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Our ECT produced stable results ECTN 26, but our CPST produced unstable results 28/100 end. I felt the CPST was a more accurate result since were looking at a large avalanche on a neighboring slope.
above 3 mile between Burntwood and White Pine

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This pit graph is the approximate summation of the snowpack within 100 meters of the gps location. Tests were done in various pits within 100 meters of the gps location. Could not reproduce the ECTP result at 50cm. Subsequent shovel shear tests and ECTs revealed that this unstable test result was an outlier and appeared to be isolated. But this layer will need to be considered on other slopes, and going into the future. Steepness was between 25 and 30° in the multiple pits. Aspect of 35° is approximate.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: No cracking or collapsing. Lots of loose snow avalanches on steep slopes off the ridge. Stability was good and skiing was great!
Strong to gale force east winds still able to move light to moderate amounts of snow. Some facets were observed above the basal ice but were inconsistent throughout the snowpit.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: top center of Rendezvous Bowl. Snowpack in that area rated STABLE. Although weak layer present, no real slab and lots of rock anchors.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche:
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Above treeline continues to remain heavily wind affected and firm... strong NW winds persisted today with visible blowing snow. Cold temps/high winds sublimating snow prevented any significant wind slab build up above TL. Near and below treeline, variable conditions continue. Only shady and protected aspects, mostly NW/N/NE hold soft snow. Otherwise, a variable thickness breakable surface crust exists on most southerly aspects.

Snowmobile tracks on slope; We snowmobiled slope
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wind affected above treeline. Widespread sun crust of varying thickness on many aspects. Skiing not that great, funky, variable, breakable crust, some softer powder in areas. A few thin weak layers in top 43cm, but not of serious concern at this point and with mostly sun in the forecast, I don't suspect any weak layers to linger. Total height of snow at pit location - 130cm. Bottom 87cm rock solid.
